description.text:
A front mount for the Eachine EF-02 FPV AIO camera! Just clears those props. The LEDs are visible from the bottom! Also, an antenna guard to protect the cloverleaf antenna. The spacer is for the rear screws, so that they come down the same as the front screws with the mount.

My weight without battery is 46.21 grams.

Dissatisfied with the VM275T, I wanted to try something different. I sometimes have a hard time flying outdoors with the VM275T, with the horizon nicely exposed, but the ground being completely dark. The EF-02 seemed like it might handle wide dynamic range a bit better, from videos I have seen. Plus it has a 1/3 inch CMOS! The cloverleaf antenna should provide a slightly better signal, while still being roughly the same weight as the VM275T. Tucking the camera in the front of the drone should be a nice way to keep it protected, and it makes room to put the cloverleaf antenna on top with a guard, without sticking up too much. The LEDs are on the bottom edge of the camera, with an open back, the mount still leaves them exposed!

Printer:

Custom Rostock

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed mine out of PETG. I think nylon would be okay for the camera mount, but I think the stiffer quality of the PETG is good for the antenna guard.

Please note that the fit with the camera is fairly snug, so you may need to do some post-printing cleanup. Also, be very careful! It should fit nicely, but not too tight! Don't try to force it. I am not responsible for any lenses that break off!

title: Embedded Skull Dice for Transparent 3D Printing

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KesvLciE8rw

This is a simple dice with a skull-shaped void inside it. In order to see the skull you need to use a transparent print process. Theoretically SLA should work (but lacking an SLA printer I haven't tried). For FFF printing, Colorfabb HT will work if you can print it hot enough and have an enclosure and can turn off the fan and turn your settings down to print fairly slow. See the video for ideal print settings.

This must be printed without supports or it will ruin the void.

There's still some question about orientation. The skull can't print facing up, the eye holes need support, so should I print it on the bottom or the side? The bottom tends to be very clear, but if you haven't had a perfect purge that's a no-go. But on the side any bubbles in the print become very visible. There's no clear answer to this one, pun intended, but I think if you printed these I'd say skull down, and that's how I uploaded it.

comments.text: I did manage to print this using a Form2; @20mm it's about 8.56ml of resin just under 2hours.  I had some remaining in the bottom tray before swapping to a different cartridge so I did a test... unfortunately some clear resin still remains on the inside of the hollow after the print which is to be expected as the Form2 "drips" the resin off as the model/build platform is submerged into the resin chamber layer by layer. Essentially the model looks like there's water trapped in the middle of an ice cube - skull is still visible but obscured by the trapped resin.

comments.text: 200% wow!! its gonna be huge!! anyway its pretty straight forward the parts were either hot glued or super glued (i used lock-tite gel. or any super glue gel will do) together i started withe the main body glued the face and the weights in with super glue.i super glued the front part of the top to the body(do not glue the back part with the smoke stacks(this need to be removable) I also glued the jib together with super glue then attached it to the top with 3m bolt and nut ( your gonna have to use bigger maybe 4m or 5m not sure). i then used a 3m bolt and nut to attach the body to the tower. then i used hot glue to attach the bottom the the tower to the mid base. next i printed 4 of the tower part 2s and attached them together with zip ties then hot glued it to the bottom of the mid base. as you can see by the pic i hot glued this on top of a wooden base for extra weight and stability. Then Crankys' signs super glued to the upper back of the body right above the weights. the crank cylinder goes into the body, the crank and the plate attach on either side with some wood screws and some super glue. i put another 3m bolt and nut at the top of the jib. I attached some string to the crank cylinder and fished it up threw the jib up over the bolt and nut at the top. i also had to add a separate string from the jib to the top as pictured. you are gonna have to get bigger magnets to add to the hook. or make an actual hook and thats it please sent pics i would love to see him at 200% thanks!!

author: MetalHeadz

title: mould for making multiple universal light coupler devices
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The print here will allow for the production of unlimited numbers of the universal light coupler. Please refer to published article "The universal light coupler" in The Laryngoscope for full details (http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/lary.26656/abstract;jsessionid=24784C37EE3CD0365F16F4980DC654A4.f03t01)

The coupling device is produced by pouring silicone into a prefabricated mould, available to download here. The mould has been designed and subsequently printed in 3d using Acrylonitrile butadiene styrene (ABS).

The silicone components are delivered as two component low viscous liquids, which once mixed and cured, transform into a translucent, elastic and resistant material. Equal parts are mixed and poured into the mould. Typically 40ml of silicone which is held in place using either a 8cm length of 3.2 cm diameter plastic piping (commonly used for plumbing and costing less than £2 for 2 meters), or a 3d printed cylinder. The mould was designed using Autodesk® 123d® printing software available for free.

After the two silicon components have been mixed, poured into the mould and allowed to cure, the mould can be taken apart and the silicon coupling device released from the mould. A releasing agent is recommended to facilitate the extraction of the coupling device from the mould. Pigments can be added and are widely available.

The coupling device can be fitted with a pen torch and attached to a wide range of commonly used medical devices. A variant of the flexible scope which has a long lead attachment for a boxed light source is commonly used. The coupling device can be used by inserting a standard adult disposable aural speculum which is slightly modified by trimming 6mm of the distal end. Alternatively a long lead specific coupling device can be made using the same principles but with a slightly modified mould (figure 3 and 4).

The author would recommend careful selection of torches and advises not to use torches which have a head diameter of greater than 13mm.

If institutions or individuals would like support or an example of the device please visit http://drbeegun.com/

Hi,
Also if now GEEETech proposes the Acrylic Prusa I3 pro series, B for single extruder and C for dual extruder, with metallic idler, I’ve see lot of people that still download my old customization for Printed idler, so I’ve think good to “port” the new version of my customization also on old, printed idler!
Here the Mono Extruder FAN & LED component of my new customization.
In this design you can find place to put ties in order keep in position all cables, as you can see in my photos!
For FAN Duct you can find closed & open version, I prefer closed one but I know that lot of people can love open version!
The component is designed to support also the 3DTouch sensor that GEEETech is released to implement ABL!

PS: I’ve also add the STL for carriage with some small enhancement compared to original GEEETech ones, for example the x belt fixing method copied from the metal carriage, really more easy to put in place, and Nut space on extruder holder where screw add-on!

As usual in all my design I’ve splitted all in order to have an easy print of each part, and also an easy mounting after print!

IF YOU “FALL IN LOVE” OF THIS DESIGN, PLEASE, REMEMBER THAT IT TAKE TIME TO BE CREATED, DESIGNED AND SHARED… SO “MAYBE” YOU CAN USE THE “TIP DESIGNED” BUTTON ON MY PROFILE!

title: Flexible Magnetic bit holder attachment for FR4 machine shield
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
First, thank you to Pocket NC for creating the FR4 Machine shield! Visit them at: http://www.pocketnc.com.

This is my design for an attachment that performs the duties of a lid/door catch, a magnetically attached (see Misc. Notes for magnet descriptions) bit holder, and a hall sensor bypass.

PLEASE NOTE: You must read all of the following text/instructions. There are hints that might help with assembly of the parts. As with my flexible coupler design, this model should be printed with a properly calibrated FDM printer using Makerflex or Ninjaflex filaments only. For safe, experimental testing only by adults 18 years of age or older. Use at your own risk in a safe environment away from face and hands, as well as all minors, and other creatures... Let me know what you think of this add-on for the FR4 machine shield!

If you like this thing, show me by tipping me and click the 'TIP DESIGNER' button at: http://www.thingiverse.com/kellectibles/about. Also buy my jewelry at: http://www.kellectibles.com. Thank You!

Best,
Steve H.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3096 or finer is recommended

Notes:

Filament used: Makergeeks Makerflex (lemon flavor)
Print speed: This filament should be reduced to <20 mm/s. And bottom layer set to <10 mm/s.
Retraction speed: ~40 mm/s
Retraction distance: ~2 mm
BUT OF COURSE,
Adjust all settings & salt to taste. Enjoy!

Multi-function attachment displaying the recommended and DIY installed ten (10) 6mm (diameter) x 5mm (Length) magnets Multi-function attachment being retured the holder. With optional magnets installed, the bit holder may even be held upside down with good reliability. But regardless, you should not be careless and lose them or let them fall out! My source for the magnets used was kmart but you can also find the exact magnets here:

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008RMRV8C/ref=s9_dcacsd_dcoop_bw_c_x_5_w

Please note: I've seen these packages of magnets come with shorter magnets mixed in with the ones pictured (i.e. the pictured magnets of 6mm diameter X 5mm length mixed in with those that are only 6mm diameter X ~1.5mm in length!) so beware. Multiple packages may need to be purchased or from a different source. For this purpose, the magnets of 6mm diameter X 5mm length are the only size used! Although the smaller kind might work, the caveats are that the bits will ride lower in the holder, and their tips will not be as visible when placed in the bit holder. Care would need to be taken not to place those magnets too deep -- and yet those smaller magnets could dislodge more easily. I have not tested this attachment with the inferior smaller magnets. Thanks.

Final note about assembly of Parts 1 and 3 and fixing the lid stop part to the base part:

The lid stop (Part 3) CAN be installed onto the base (Part 1) if properly leveraged with a rigid object such as a wooden popsicle stick. These parts were made with a tight tolerance to ensure rigidity of the connection, and being that it's printed with flexible filament, the tolerance needs to be tight if you want the lid stop option to work. So do this step slowly and carefully by inserting the stick into the square hole of Part 3 (lid stop part) and use caution and common sense to work the parts together. Or, alternatively, have an experienced hobbiest/maker install it for you. Check out the video below for a demonstration of how to do this...

How to install the lid stop (part 3) to the base (part 1) in record time.

Some parts require supports.

Stuff required:
4 mm shaft - 2 pieces about 185 mm and one piece about 220 mm
18 gauge brads - 5/8" long
self-tapping screws - #4 1/2" and 3/4"
set screws and nuts - #6 about 1/4"
extension springs - 13/64" and 13/16" - Harbor Freight Item # 67562
small eye screws
Gear Motor - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01KTZXZDE/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Motor Speed Control Switch Controller - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B019H4DDIA/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
12V 2.5A AC-DC Adapter - Radio Shack Item # 273-318 or similar or 12V battery.
PWM Controller Housing - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1958914 - needs to be stretched.

Assembly Instructions:
Clean up the parts after printing them.
Assemble the transmission as shown at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1958914 but do the following:
Put C2 Clutch Fork in Case before putting C2 Clutch Slider in Case.
Put C1 Clutch Fork in Case before putting C1 Clutch Slider in Case.
Put long bushing between rear of case and clutch button.
Put short bushings between clutch buttons.
Drill holes in case for springs.
Looking at the front of the transmission, the large gear should rotate clockwise.

description.text:
I've had an ongoing project to improve the part cooling on my Printrbot Play. I've finally got the solution I needed. This shroud incorporates the standard 20x20mm square fan for extruder cooling and a 50mm radial fan for part cooling.

The shroud is tapped for 3mm button head screws in four places to secure the fans. Note that I ground down the radial fan tabs about 2mm just under the screw heads so the screws do not extend beyond the face of the fan. This provides clearance to the Printrbot enclosure should the x-axis go to the max.

The fan duct for the square fan is tapped for 3mm screws as well.

The "pb" lettering was done on Cricut Explore Air.

I'll note this as a remix even though my starting point was the metal shroud that came with the Printrbot Play. That said, I was likely influenced in part by crazygood33's design.

author: mabowat

title: Chess set with checkers like pieces

description.text:
I designed this chess set for the McFarland Youth Center (McFarland, WI, USA) where I volunteer to build a chess club.

The board is 20x20 (inch) Russian Baltic Birch which I found at a local building store.

The chess board was drawn on the board and then burned into it (pyrography) after which an acrylic wash (diluted artist pigment) was used to color the 'black' (green) squares while letting the grain show through. The MYC logo was also burned into the board's corners but then painted in solid acrylic.

The chess pieces consist of a base, a cup of 1mm thick PLA, which was filled with Portland cement (Quick-Crete) to give the pieces a solid feel.

Once the cement, which was level with the top of each 'cup', was fully cured the top was painted with a thin coat of black acrylic to provide a solid background for the piece icons.

The icons which identify each chess piece were 3D printed in two colors - yellow and orange in this case - and were then glued onto the black acrylic topped base. (note pawns are smaller diameter bases than the other pieces).

These pieces were designed to have to look of the pieces of the chess sites found on the web so that they would be familiar to the children - as well as having the standard "rank and file" notation marked on the chess board so that they are familiar with this notation as well.

When the adhesive was dry all of the pieces received a "top coat" of thick two-part clear plastic (casting or pourable) which was carefully painted on to protect the pieces from their middle school users ;-)

Design notes

The design for the chess pieces was derived from a screenshot of one of the online chess sites (lichess.org, chessclub.com, etc.) and then imported into Inkscape.

The designs were then 'cleaned up', cropped, modified, etc. to produce the .svg files given.

FreeCAD was then used to create the .stl file by importing the .svg files ('image' workbench)
and then (after re-sizing the image for 25x25 mm) using the 'part design' workbench - to create a sketch in the same plane (the .svg image in background).

Note: The pawns were 'padded' thinner than the larger pieces for their .stl files.

Model Diesel Engine Starter

This is prototyping a Model Diesel Engine Starter ONLY:

The main spring would not, (most likely at least if printed in ABS*), turn with enough torque to start a Model Diesel Engine.

*PLA is said to be even worse for springs.

Other filament types may be better, or a metal spring may be needed.

The basic idea is to wind up a spring, (clockwork type spring), against a ratchet and then hold the Starting Lid against the Model Diesel Engine Spinner/Propellor and release the ratchet.

This should turn enough turns to start a Model Diesel Engine.

Cura says the main spring could take "over" 20 hours to print. 100% infill for strength.

I have not 3D Printed this version of a Model Diesel Engine Starter I have tried some other smaller types "prototyping only" and this has lead to making this improved, bigger spring more turning design.

More design changes, fitting, and testing are required.

These files are supplied as is.

Here is a YouTube Play List of some of the other prototyping of this Model Diesel Engine Starter:-

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUqt0sTiXUDdcmmreGoee2sW6Nck3aPFl

TinkerCAD and Cura

TinkerCAD and Cura

The main drive spring will take many hours to print and may not even work as hoped.

Programming fixture for ESP-12F modules.
Requires:
16 pcs. PL75-B1 spring test probes.
1 pcs. Wemos D1 mini with ESP-12F module on board.

Remove the ESP-12F module from the Wemos board (use heat gun).
Clean the Wemos board and glue (epoxy) the printed center-block to the Wemos board (assemble the full fixture to align the Wemos board and the center block while the epoxy is hardening).
Mount the test probes in the center-block and solder to Wemos board.

The ESP-12F module must be held against the test probes during the programming.

title: Region Free Super Famicom Cartridge Back Panel

description.text:
This is the back portion to a Super Famicom cartridge. It can be used to create a completely new blank SF cartridge (front portion not included) or it can be used to modify an authentic cartridge as I have done [Pictured]. This panel is region free, in so far as it includes the notches that fit over the corresponding posts seen in the cartridge slot of the US SNES (IE: if you replace an authentic SF cart's back panel with this thing it will allow it to physically fit in the cartridge slot of a standard SNES).

(FYI: If you're using Cura and want usagi_'s design logo and "Nintendo" text to appear you need to print the initial layer at at most 0.2 resolution. Otherwise it just wont show up on the final print.)

I purposefully made the holes for the screws too small (1mm), with the expectation that the end user will drill, bore, tap them to fit whatever screws they happen to be using. I personally use a small metal sanding cone with my dremel to widen the holes and just bore the original Super Famicom cart screws in place (I know I should be using a tap, but I don't have one small enough yet), but to each their own.

I designed this thing using Tinkercad. I imported the back portion of usagi_'s wonderfully dimensionally accurate Super Famicom cartridge design and made it functional using the guts of CCalo's SNES Cartridge design, while also making a few modifications for strength and compatibility with an authentic SF cart.

-I added the SNES notches like I said.
-I made the center support post an elongated cube as opposed to the original cylinder: While more accurate to the original designs of both carts the original cylinder seen on CCalo's SNES cart design didn't come out very strong in my case (it snapped off pretty easy), so I replaced it with the aforementioned elongated cube which is much stronger.
-I made the lowermost ledge thicker: It's a bit thin on the original SNES design (it printed like support material on my printer).
-I brought the screw holes down 2mm to meet the holes on a standard SF cart front portion.
-I added receiving holes to the top edge to fit the clips seen on authentic SF carts.
-I made the screw holes smaller [See Post-Printing] and taller.

comments.text: Really nice! Love the way you integrated it with the original front cartridge.
comments.author: CCalo

description.text:
After a lot of tweaking and toying around with this design, this is the final.

This uses a 22mm bearing and 4, 1/2 inch steel ball bearings.

For the 1/2 inch bearing placement I channeled it out slightly so that the ball bearings have room to move so you can roll this spinner around on a surface or with your finger or thumb.

Included is an STL for the Caps that I used

Updates
4.13.17 - Added 7 Bearing Mini Spinner. This Spinner uses 3/8 Inch Ball Bearings and was suggested and tested by jmartellotta

Enjoy!

author: Makeoneortwo

title: E3D Mount with Inductive Sensor for Openbuilds Gantry Plate.

description.text:
I'm in the process of building a new X-Carriage using a 2020 V-Slot rail as the crossmember. As such I've been experimenting with different gantry plate designs that would be compatible with the parts I've either got on-hand or bought.

As such I've made this mount for the ubiquitous E3D hot end. It also has mounting for a 12MM diameter inductive probe for auto bed leveling.

the key to this is the mounting points. They are designed to align with the gantry plate as sold by Openbuilds and others. The screw spacing in the center of the mount is 10MM between holes. This also matches up to my self designed gantry plate as shown here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2202323

The offsets between the probe and the center of the hot end are X-axis -30MM, Y-Axis -7MM. In plain English the probe is 30MM to the left of the hot end and 7MM forward.

If you need this or anything else I've designed printed I can help. I specialize in HIPS and ABS printing for strong parts. Just send me a message.

description.text:
A simple case to give some protection too and hold a Raspberry PI computer board.
Thanks to Lee for the loan of the Raspberry PI and photos.

I have printed the case on a Makerbot Thing-o-matic using Replicatorg.
The case attempts to hold the Raspberry PI PCB and so it is quite a tight fit.  Don't try and force the PCB into the case or you may damage the Raspberry PI :( 
The stand-offs should hold the Raspberry PI PCB, but depending on the accuracy of your printer may need a small amount of modification after printing.
Please note that the model may not print correctly if Replicatorg isn't used, so check the output before printing using something like Pleasant3D to view the generated g-code.
I have added a v2 STL file that hopefully corrects the manifold errors in the first version of the model.  This should now slice correctly in Slic3r.
I have added a version with mounting tabs so that I can mount the RPi onto things more easily.

comments.text: The power connector hole isn't quite wide enough for my cables to go all the way in. The tip touches, but isn't wide enough for the rest to go past. The plastic connector on several of my USB cables are 10mm wide, but the hole is only ~9mm wide. I've adjusted the model for myself, but I figured I would let you know.

description.text:
This is a tensioner mount for adjusting belt tension with the Z-Syncher installed. Flathead screws are used so that the minimum amount of build height is lost. I used a 752mm closed loop belt(https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B018JLCBEY/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1) and two 60 tooth pulleys (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01G1N1CI8/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1). The bearings are the same as those used on the rest of the Voron build. Due to using 60 tooth pulleys, very little belt tension is needed to keep them from skipping teeth.

V2 update: I had a problem on one of my Vorons with the Z motors "fighting" each other. I found that one side of the belt would get tight while the other side was loose. The added files and pictures are the V2 version (Print 2 arms)(Optional arms with 4mm holes if needed). I am having trouble finding small, low tension springs so I am using a Dental band to pull the 2 arms together. It takes very little tension on the belt, one dental band seems to work well. Any small, thin rubber band should work. I would prefer a spring but I am too lazy at the moment to make one.

This is a battery holder to deliver 6V by linking 4 AA batteries in series.

Assembly

I used ABS. Two parts are glued together to form one piece. A tab in each section ensures the polarity is aligned properly.
Three 1/4"x1-5/8"xx0.016" brass bars are used to connect the batteries. The thin bars slide into slots at the ends of the battery holder then bent in to form contacts for the batteries.
Two small brass bolts (#4-40 x 3/8") serve as terminals to which wires can be connected with nuts or soldered. Polarity of the batteries is marked in the ends of the holder.

Use complete file for both parts together, or box and lid if you want to print them individually.

This is a modified version of the housing made by dstark. This one is for the US-100 ultrasonic sensor. Since the sensors position are different, I had to modify the lid. I made the modification from the stl version of the model (didn't notice sources were available at the time). For this reason, the lid model file is really large and the model has some small glitches, but it didn't show up on the print.

I also increased the height of the box to allow the inclusion of the back pins and I increased the size of the top connector for the 5 pins of the US-100.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

0.1

Notes:

I used support for the hole at the top of the housing, but it is probably not necessary. Should be an easy print.

It's important that the print doesn't shrink or the sensor won't fit. The lid is really tight.

Assembly

Lid is really tight.

To assemble, just fit the sensor in the lid first. The pins should be on the lower side of the lid. The sensor should fit really tight and once correctly inserted in the lid, it should be flat with the base of the lid. Once it's correctly inserted, just place the pins in line with the base and insert the lid in the base.

DIY FPV Race Gate V1

An easy to make, lightweight DIY gate for drone racing.

I have included all the connections I have designed for my DIY FPV racing gates that are very lightweight, strong and easy on your quad when you hit them.

The gates are made from 22mm diameter PVC pipe and pipe lagging or swimming pool noodles.

I have also included a 22mm joiner so you can half the main 57" section into 2 and join them together if you need to travel a little more compact.

If you have any questions feel free to ask.

TUBING
4x : 22mm PVC tube 15"
2x : 22mm PVC tube 24"
1x : 22mm PVC tube 57"

CONNECTORS
2x : 22mm PVC pipe 4 way connector (Included here)
4x : 22mm PVC pipe end cap (included here)

FOAM
3x : Swimming pool noodles or foam pipe lagging

I made this little "thing" to help a couple people I know. They are always having difficul;ty in opening their cans of pet foods, the ones that pull back. So I made them this, and dubbed it "The Helping Hand"

This model suits the original Eachine QX90 micro FPV racing quadcopter, with a camera modification

I got some inspirations from the FireFlo v3 by SirQuentin, and the orientable camera mount of the Eachine Falcon 250.

Printer:

µDelta Original

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

17%

Electronics improvements:
  • I've separated the VTX part from the camera, I recommend the muteFPV youtube channel tutorial
  • I've add a connector to the camera battery wires to facilitate the assembly.
Frame features:
  • I've placed the VTX at the back end of the frame, horizontally, to get its antenna away from propellers and free space on the middle for the flight controller board.
  • The flysky fs-i6 transmitter and its antenna are protected inside the frame itself along with the camera connector.
  • The camera is placed on the front end of the frame, inside a protective and orientable mount. You have a nice field of view cleared from original propellers, motors and arms. You will need a piece of piano wire to make the pivot.
    I recommend a little bit of glue to seal it properly.
  • I've modeled a cover part to protect all the eletronic on the top of the frame.
    There are little hook-like shape to hold it in place thanks to rubber band, as shown on the picture above. I like to print it in ABS for material strength.
  • The whole quad rests on a nacelle connected with three shock absorbers, in my case recycled from an old CD-drive but your can use those for camera gimbal. The battery fits inside the nacelle, it's very well anchored and protected. This setup absorb shoks from landings and crashes.
  • I designed propellers guards specifically to this frame to keep it light, but you can use any kind of QX90 guard propellers since I kept the exact original dimensions.
Observations

This whole setup makes this micro FPV Racing quad crash-proof, low-profil, with comfortable camera field of view. The weight whith my print config is 50g without battery and prop guard.

description.text:
Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rbaiFQXlgCE
I made some designs for motorising a mountainboard, enjoy!

Please BEWARE that this board runs on 50 VOLTS which can be DANGEROUS working with if you don't take precautions.
Be safe and have fun!

Partslist
Hardware:

  • a mountainboard (duh!)
    https://www.mbs.com/boards/10101-mbs-colt-90-mountainboard-constellation
  • 10 tooth motor gear (2)
    http://www.ebay.com/itm/8mm-Bore-10-Teeth-10T-Metal-Pilot-Motor-Gear-Roller-Chain-Drive-Sprocket-/371683035348?hash=item568a0908d4
  • 68 tooth wheel gear (2)
    http://www.ebay.com/itm/ATV-Quad-25H-68-Tooth-Rear-Chain-Sprocket-For-47cc-49cc-Pocket-Bike-Mini-Moto-/112000123860?hash=item1a13ba43d4
  • chain
    http://www.robotshop.com/eu/en/andymark-25-single-strand-riveted-roller-chain-10-feet.html
  • chain links (2)
    http://www.robotshop.com/eu/en/connecting-link-roller-chain-25.html
  • m4 bolts 5cm (10)
  • m5 locknuts (30)
  • m8 locknuts (6)
  • m5 threaded rod ~26cm (6)
  • m5 bolts or rod 6cm (2)
  • m8 threaded rod ~20 cm (2)

Electronics:

  • vesc (2)
    http://diyelectricskateboard.com/diy-electric-skateboard-kits-parts/vesc-the-best-electric-skateboard-esc/
    http://shop.faradaymotion.com/shop/18-electronics/4-vesc-motor-controller/
  • Turnigy SK3 192kv (or any other 12s brushless ~200kv motor) (2)
    i got this one: https://hobbyking.com/en_us/turnigy-aerodrive-sk3-6374-192kv-brushless-outrunner-motor.html
    here is another option: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Maytech-6374-190KV-e-bike-electric-motor-longboard-motor/32666982968.html?ws_ab_test=searchweb201556_7,searchweb201602_4_10017_507_401,searchweb201603_1&btsid=bac5c47f-cf08-4292-b0fc-a6355c35e43c
  • Batteries (make sure the C rating is high enough)
    i got 8 of these cause they were on sale at the time: https://hobbyking.com/en_us/multistar-high-capacity-3s-5200mah-multi-rotor-lipo-pack.html
  • RC car radio
    https://hobbyking.com/en_us/hobbyking-gt2e-afhds-2a-2-4ghz-2-channel-radio-system.html

Remember to get wires, charger and connectors for the batteries if you don't have any.
I also recommend an antispark xt90 between the batteries and electronics.

description.text:
This is a remix of a paperweight made to hang on your wall.

I took out the back and made it shorter (less bulky) , cut it in four pieces and enlarged each piece to fit an average bed size (<20x20), made it overall thinner but keeping the details, punched 4 holes in the back.

Advice on making this:

At the back there are lines cut out to make glue -ing easier (glue gun advised), you can do it other ways. The front for me should be primed, sanded and painted - but that's up to you.

I searched for mks tft28 on this website, and they were all complex, multiple parts with screws, mobile part, upper and lower part... I chose one that looked fine and it sucked, so i decided to design one.

This is single print. the device is hot glued in it. But anyways, it's just tight enough, glue was an option here...

Than the case is screwed on a wood based 3d printer. Like mendel 90 or case-rap.

It probably can be modified to fit other types of printer easily.

By the way I very love my mks tft28, it "pimps" my case-rap 5 model.

Printer:

Case-rap 5.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2 mm layer height

Infill:

40%

title: Cheap and quick RC car, easy to print

description.text:
https://youtu.be/5wmW5UzY6Gg

This started out with a challenge. Design and build a mostly 3d printed car then have a contest to see which is best. Our challenge rules were: cost: $40 not including electronics or filament. you'll notice that I mixed metric and inch parts, that's what I happen to be able to get locally. This is what I came up with.

This car needs 230mm X travel to be printed. I'm including the solid files from 123d design so the chassis file can be modified to print on a 200mm print bed.

Hardware needed:
Radio system with mini metal gear servo for steering
Motor/ESC, I used a 3650 motor combo that sells for $37
Battery: 2200mah 3 cell or smaller
5x225mm shaft for rear axle.
5x10x4 bearings Qty 4 (ID/OD/W)
48P spur gear, I used an Associated 31332 80t part. Take the right rear wheel into a hobby shop and they will hook you up.
Pinion for your motor. Mine is 20 tooth.
100mm 3/16th rod for front axles
3/16x1/2x3/16 bearings Qty 4 for front wheels
1/16 music wire for steering linkage
2 1/16 collars, 2 1/8 collars for steering linkage.
4 1.9" tires, usually sold for crawlers
3 shocks, I used a cheap copy of associated t4.2 shocks 2Front, 1Rear
M3 screws of various sizes. I forgot what all I used.

Printing:
Nothing needs supports except for the chassis, and that only needs it under the front end.
Print with 100% infill, otherwise it's way too light.
I used PLA and it's held up to a good beating so far.

Building: You can probably figure it out. Everything is straightforward with the exception of the rear axle. A groove needs to be filed into the axle shaft right where the cross holes in the wheel hub are located. Run a screw through the wheel hub holes to run through the grooves filed in the shaft. A little tricky but it's pretty sturdy.

The body parts need to be glued together. They come out stronger than I expected.

That's it. Ask if there is anything I missed. Do feel free to tweak, remix, mod, and improve this.

Printer:

Prusa MK2

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.35

Infill:

100%

description.text:
This is a small folding loom designed specifically for tablet or card weaving.

Tablet weaving is an accessible craft that is both ancient and ubiquitous and modern and obscure. Ancient peoples of all nations used this technique to create decorative or structural bands to adorn their clothing or for particular uses such as baggage straps, halters and so on.

You don't need to make this loom to engage in the craft of tablet weaving, but it sure makes it more convenient. With this loom you can wind your warp onto one end just as you would a normal weaving loom. You can then either sit it on your lap, lean it against a desk or just weave in bed, however you please. When you're done, simply fold it up and put it away. It is small enough to fit inside a satchel.

If you're interested in the craft of tablet weaving please search youtube to find many good instructional videos.

I plan to make and sell these, but don't see any reason to be secretive about it. It has been marked as non-commercial share-alike. As far as I'm concerned if you want to make 5 of the things and run a class have at it, but if I see these popping up on ebay I'll come after you like Liam Neeson on a bad day ;-)

PARTS NEEDED

To complete this, you will need the following.

Stuff from the hardware store

2 x 6mm nuts with 10 mm heads at least 26mm long
2 x 6mm bolts 10mm on outside
4 x 8mm metal stock (The pictured example is using aluminium pipe. But that is too weak. I suggest solid aluminium rod. You could use threaded steel bar as well, but it will increase the weight and it's not as easy to cut)
2 x 10mm threaded rod 40mm long (optional, for weighting the cloth beam to improve balance)

Printed parts

ML_IN
ML_OUT
MR_IN
MR_OUT
AE_WS x 2
AE_L_RS x 2
CLOTHBEAM
WARPBEAM
FLANGE x 4
RATCHET x 2
HANDLE x 2
PAWL_PEG x 2
PAWL x 2

ISSUES

It's a bit of a pain to assemble, but a video tutorial is upcoming, along with a video on how to dress the thing for weaving.

You'll want to do some tests to get the clearances just so. If I knew how to code in SCAD I'd make files from there, but I don't know how to do that so I won't. At the moment I try to get everything to fit just so, but there is one part that I can foresee being a wee bit on the tricky side. Where you attach the pawl stop to the end plates is designed to fit in and have the metal stock running through it to hold it in place.

This has been designed with the specific clearances of a specific printer in mind. Now that I have another printer I have realised that the first printer had been consistently under-extruding but I didn't know any better.

If there is demand for it I shall place calibration prints here so you can get your flow settings set just so, as if the holes for the stock are too small or the clearance where the ratchets or handles join the beams aren't right you can smash the smaller parts putting the thing together.

Of course, you could gouge the smaller parts out with a knife and apply liberal amount of superglue, I've done that during the development process. And you could tap out the holes for the stock if they're too tight and screw threaded rod in.

Please let me know, if there's interest in this, I shall upload calibration prints and instructional videos and all that good stuff. Like I say, I want to sell these so it's in my interests to do that anyway.

Cheers

title: Anet A8 - PSU cover for S-240-12
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Updates to come (02/08/2017)
Soon I'll add a slot for a key switch, so it will make the machine child safe when turned off. At this moment I'm working on a new cover, which will have a hole for a 85x46mm power consumption display. Unfortunately, there's no way to fit both with the stock PSU height.

Updates 24/07/2017
Uploaded a new version for short flange S-240-12 version. Moved all the holes 6mm higher, and also the cut where bottom side of the flange rests. Some PSUs could have that short flange, at least in the US. Measure yours before choosing normal flange (approx 18mm) or short flange (approx 12mm). Thanks to @airrelic for the input.

Updates 24/06/2017
Uploaded a new version. Changed some dimensions. Now the side bolts thread in a M3 nut, instead of in the piece itself.

This is a PSU cover for Anet A8. It fits for S-240-12 PSU and allows you to install a rocker switch socket like the one you can see in the attached picture.
Doesn't need supports, brims, or whatever...
It's reinforced in the inside. I would recommend printing on glass + hairspray, so the front part looks smooth and clean.
You can easily bolt them to the holes in front left top, and the ones in right side front top.
It should be printed with the front face on build plate. No supports needed.

You'll need:
The switch itself
1x M3x30mm bolt
2x M3x12mm bolts
2x M3 nuts
1x 5x20mm 250V 3A Breaker, Fast Blow if possible. (3A ONLY FOR 220V)
Some L, N and E wires for the AC part. (COLOUR CODE DEPENDS ON YOUR COUNTRY)
Faston terminal connectors.
Soldering iron and flux (optional)

It works for 3 Pin IEC320 C14 Rocker Switch Socket, like the one in the link below:
http://www.ebay.es/itm/181749779642?rmvSB=true

DOES IT WORK FOR 110V?
I haven't tested it for 110V, so input from any place in North/Central/South America would be most welcome. As long as the PSU is set for 110V and the switch works for 110V and is prepared to deal with a higher current, it should work. Ask your electric stuff supplier just in case.

BobPantz made this remix for Multicomp JR-101-1-FRSG-03 Rocker Switch Socket (UK)

If you make one feel free to hit "I made one" button. Feel free to give feedback :D

ABOUT THE SWITCHS
Some switchs out there have three terminals, while some others have four. For that reason, I won't provide any wiring diagram. The wiring info should be provided by the manufacturer in the datasheet. Sorry for the inconvenience.

DISCLAIMER:
Of course, this mod demands some AC wiring. This step can be dangerous and could cause major injuries or even death, as well as a fire or damage to your printer or any other part of your home.
Do it at your own risk.
Safety measures must be taken.
Never work on the wiring with the printer plugged.
Check the datasheet of the manufacturer before doing the wiring.
Check the wiring with a tester before switching on.

Anet A8

comments.text: Hi my friend! I want to print this model, just I have a doubt, the PSU need to receive the 110v or 220v for the connector, but then, there is ( usually ) four wires that came from the PSU to the Arduino board, where can I route this four wires? thanks in advance!
comments.author: cronosgba

comments.text:
Hi, just checked mine and it only has two (DC) wires (a red one and a black one) sticking out from the PSU. They deliver current to the mainboard (I keep the stock one, not Arduino+RAMPS. Besides, there are, of course, L, N and E wires for AC, where you wire the switch.
There's a hole in the stock frame right behind bottom-right corner of the PSU. So I put the wire through that hole, then all the way across the printer and beneath the M8 threaded rods, and then through an equal hole in the piece where mainboard is bolted. Then of course, to the mainboard terminals.

title: 40x20 fan mount and ducts with wire management

description.text:
Designed a fan mount/adaptor to use a 40x20 fan to replace the standard 50x15. Fan is smaller and quieter. Some 50mm fans are also too powerful and can result in lowering the hotend/nozzle temps and make the temps fluctuate more as well as work the heater unnecessarily.
Mount is design to fit in place of the 50mm fan with a clamp up top and spacer on the bottom bolts to fit without mods to the actual printer structure.
(note, this is for a 26mm length heat break tube on an MK8 style hotend, )

Ducts snap onto mount
upper clamp holds top of fan in place
spacer allows for stock bolt to be used
the whole unit is lightly adjustable to fit in place.
Ducts are postioned to cover just the tip of the nozzle with out blocking it like "ring " ducts do to ease hotend maintenance.

Should work on most i3 style printers with the 50mm fan mounted on the front. the ducts snap on so they can be reconfigured to your personal printer if needed.

title: Parametric Olympus reversible lens hood sized for 75-300

description.text:
This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:240706 with a few enhancements:

  • It separates the bayonet flange from the inner end of the hood, so the diameter can be enlarged for reversibility.
  • There's a test mode (in the .scad version) that prints just the bayonet, for quick size testing.
  • It's a bit shorter (but this is easily controlled by parameters).

This is currently sized for a good fit on the Olympus m4/3 75-300mm, but is probably adaptable to other Olympus variations.

Pictures show an aftermarket copy of the LH-61E hood for comparison.

UPDATE

The v4 files incorporate a few improvements.

  • There's now a locking nub on the bayonet. This still isn't quite right, so look for a v5, but the fit is snugger.
  • There's a "filter" mode that creates a flat rim instead of a hood, so you can glue on Baader AstroSolar film (I did this for the eclipse).

Current files:

lens_hood4.scad is the parametric creator, from OpenSCAD
lens_hood4.stl is the rendered hood
lens_hood4-filter.stl is the filter-mode version
lens_hood4-ringonly.stl is just the bayonet ring, for test fitting

author: Strange_Meadowlark

description.text:
When remixing OpenSCAD Graph Generator ||, I remembered one thing I still didn't challenge. That is, using the built-in polyhedron module to create a function graph.

This is a demonstration of the function_grapher module in my library. It's easy to use. For example.

include <line3d.scad>;
include <polyline3d.scad>;
include <function_grapher.scad>;

function f(x, y) = 
   30 * (
       cos(sqrt(pow(x, 2) + pow(y, 2))) + 
       cos(3 * sqrt(pow(x, 2) + pow(y, 2)))
   );

thickness = 2;
min_value =  -200;
max_value = 200;
resolution = 10;

points = [
    for(y = [min_value:resolution:max_value])
        [
            for(x = [min_value:resolution:max_value]) 
                [x, y, f(x, y)]
        ]
];

function_grapher(points, thickness);

For more information, please take a look at dotSCAD.
If you're interested in how to design a function_grapher module, take a look at "Function grapher".

• OpenSCAD Documentation - Traditional Chinese
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - English

description.text:
A printable version of an LM8UU holder used in the Anet A8 and A6 printer ranges as well as others. Each print of this will also require 2 cable ties to hold the bearing in place. Ideally the holes on the back side will also need to be drilled and tapped with an M4 thread.

I plan to design a belt holder to go alongside this part for the A8 x-axis.

If using this design on the y axis you might find that your y endstop will no longer trigger as the bearing will go straight past the endstop that it would normally hit. I plan to revise this design to provide a separate bearing model eventually. For the time being spigandromeda took the time to make a part to raise the y endstop height to work around this issue. You can find this model in the comments or at the following link: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2536867

The pictures show both sides of the holder after tapping the holes and fitting the cable ties, bearing / bushing and screws.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 or 0.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

When printing in PLA I used a fan speed 15% for high volume air blowers or 40-50% for low volume air blowers.

2 cable ties required per printed piece.
Tapping of the four screw holes to M4 thread recommended. May be possible to force a thread directly with the screw but not recommended. I would not recommend threading through the entire length of the hole. The fit shown in the picture was achieved by threading to the point where the bit was about level with the exit hole.

Measurement of original parts and bearings - design in OpenSCAD.

Unless someone has printed this variant and confirmed it works please consider this untested and print accordingly (1 to test perhaps?).

24/07/2017

  • 0.6mm extra distance between the screw mounting side and the centre of the bearing mounting position.
  • 0.4mm Increase in the length of the recess to hold bearing. This should allow for a slightly looser fit requested recently.

10/04/2017

09/04/2017

  • Altered design to have holes through the part for easier tapping.
  • Repositioned cable tie holes to not intersect with the screw holes.
  • Previous version would not work well with screws inserted more than 4mm into the part.

08/04/2017

  • Resizing of cable tie holes
  • Resized bearing recess
  • Changed cable tie holes to have a gap in the back of the part rather than a hole in the top to improve strength of the part.

remixed_from.author: superpotatofudge
remixed_from.title: CR-10 40mm Stock Hot End Cooling Duct

title: Radial Fan Fang for Creality CR-10

description.text:
Here is a remix of Lion4H's Radial Fan Fang to be able to mount to a 40mm x 40mm hot end fan instead of an E3D 30mm fan. Specifically designed to work on a Creality CR-10 with superpotatofudge's hot end cooling duct and the stock hot end and cooling fan. Requires the use of a 5015 radial blower fan like the original design. Blender file included to allow modifications, just look at Lion4H's thing for instructions. Probably works for afinitbot and CR-7/8 as well.

Updates:

  • 4/9/2017: Thickened fan mounting bracket that connects to the hot end fan as original was a little thin and was buckling when tightened down along the bottom of the mount. Haven't tested yet, but shouldn't be any issues with this version.
  • 4/29/2017: Version 2 of the no probe fang duct that mounts between the fan and superpotatofudge's hot end cooling duct. A little thicker for durability.
  • 5/7/2017: Added new version that thickens the 5015 mounting fins.
  • 5/27/2017: Updated photos to reflect how the thicker version should be installed. Pictures show version slightly different than the ones uploaded that will be released once tested that includes a mini-ir probe mount below the fan.

description.text:
This is a double helical geared fidget spinner. Friction fit between bearings. No additional hardware needed. The center bearing is held in place by surrounding gears.

You'll need to print:
4 x DoubleHelixGear
2 x Spinner
2 x Bearing Button

Used four 22mm bearings (608Z)

Print the gears, spinners, and buttons. You'll need to push the bearings into the gears, this might require pliers but be careful not to break the gears. Push the bearing buttons into each side of one of the bearings. Next, we need to push one of the bearings onto the spinner piece, this may require pliers also. Then line up the bearing that has the buttons in the middle of the spinner piece making sure that the gears fit interlocking with the gears on the bearing that is attached to the spinner. Then push the other two bearings onto the spinner piece ensuring that the gears line up with the middle bearing gears. Finally push the other spinner piece into the bearings to finish assembly.

Please let me know if there are any improvements that can be made!

Printer:

Custom Built Delta (Delta-Six)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

I printed this with a 1.2mm nozzle at 0.6mm layer height. This should work with any other settings.

title: Adpators for geeetech 20x4 to Prusa MK2 lcd case

description.text:
I put a geeetech 20x4 lcd into a Original Prusa MK2 lcd case

For the most part It fits nicely.
Display lines up, SD card lines up, Screws are slightly out but close enough.
The knob shaft and reset button are in correct location, but are two far back/short.

These two parts fix this without having to modify the lcd case parts.

Knob_mod is an extension to the Knob clip, is glued to the current part. (Ignore the screw thread in the image, its just there to make sure it lined up correctly while gluing)
Reset_mod is an extension to the reset, it clips onto the current case parts.

title: SLA Cube Challenge and test cube

description.text: A hollow 50mm cube to challenge your SLA or resin printer's abilities and to help calibrate x, y, and z dimensional shrinkage post-cure.

Printer:

Moai

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Best

Infill:

None

Notes:

Print with Side "A" against the build plate

This has no drain holes, yet is intended to be a hollow cube. You will need to pause the print after completing the layer just before the bottom of the cube is to be printed, lift it out of the resin, and let the resin drain for a few minutes. You could insert an object into the cube (Ship in a bottle sort of thing) at this point if desired, then resume the print.

This test cube dispels the myth that you cannot print hollow objects without a drain hole in SLA, or print models without supports. All you need to do is the tool change maneuver, let the resin fully drain, then resume in the case of the hollow feature. This technique SHOULD be built into future resin printer slicers - not sure if it's in their plans.

The Moai should be able to print this model without angling the model or hanging it on an angle on supports (that result in zits on the model after the supports are removed). I don't think the FormLabs or many other machines can do this, but prove me wrong by showing your makes here.

description.text:
Q11 Jack Input Plate

These are for my Combo Amp and Extension Speakers. One hole accepts a standard ¼” Phono Jack. The other hole accepts a standard Heavy Duty Toggle Switch.

The BLANK is for you to do as you please.
The Jackport is intended for switching from a passive 3-way crossover to just using the 10” speaker.
The Jackport Ohms is intended for switching a split-coil woofer from 8 Ohms Series to 2 Ohms parallel by flipping a switch.

I created the Bodies in FUSION 360.

STEP file is included for the BLANK version. Add your own text, and/or change the hole sizes for different purposes. have fun! You should be able to resize it, or study and make your own custom adaptation.

This was sliced and coded using ReplicatorG employing 2 shells (3 total) using PLA.

  • FlashForge Creator Pro (Similar to Makerbot Replicator 2)
  • Heated Bed 45 Celsius
  • Blue Painters Tape on bed, no further treatment
  • Print Temperature 220 degrees Celsius
  • YES SUPPORT no rafts.
  • Feedrate 40 mm/s
  • Travel Feedrate 55
    (If anybody has more optimum feedrates, please share!)

REQUEST: Please help me improve my sharing! STEP files have proven reliable for me to transport file between different CAD platforms. If STEPs are a problem for you, please let me know what other common and relatively generic Cad format works better for you.

description.text:
Update - Please use 7Blade.stl - It's a greatly improved design, which provides greater thrust and efficiency. In fact, it provides greater thrust than the original fan that came with this jet.

Designed as a replacement fan for my Venom T45 50mm EDF Jet. I broke the stock one, and couldn't find a direct replacement, so decided to make my own. Should fit any 3mm threaded shaft with nut.

Static thrust is almost as much as the stock fan (maybe 85%) and is tested up to around 50k rpm without failure. I have yet to actually fly it as of uploading, but I feel like it should work okay. I expect the efficiency is not as good as the stock part either.

Please test before you fly, and use safety goggles! Spinning anything up to high RPMs can be dangerous, especially 3D printed parts. Use with caution!

description.text:
With the turboFan, this hotend is for uitimaker only. Because it use JST connect to control panel and power, the change hotend would be easy and fast.

I design a LED holder and put it with hotend. This LED lamp can make a clear field when you print something. you also can turn the lamp to suit your view.

In the STL files, you can find tow "10 coross mount" and one is use for cooper bush(in 6mm,out 8mm, long 15mm), anoher is use for line bearing(in 6mm, out 12mm, long 35mm). you can choose what you want.

about the LED lamp, i also draw a schematic diagram as a pictre in the "images folder" for you refer to.

if you want use ABS, just print the "FAN duct for ABS.stl". it means the "fan duct cutting" version. you can find the pictures in "images folder". it look like a very cute robot. :-)

The data for LED lamp:

power: 12v
resistance：1k Ohm, 1/4 watt （2 pis）
LED： Max 30 ma（4 pis）

The kits you may need also:

  • screw：M2.5 x 8 mm (10 pis)
  • screw：M2.5 x 10mm (1 pis for socket )
  • screw：M3 x 16mm (2 pis for turbo FAN)
  • screw：M3 x 10mm (1 pis)
  • nut：M3 (1 pis)
  • cooper nut: M2.5 x 4mm (12 pis)
  • JST connect: 5 teams

one of all printing parts, only the "FAN_Duct,stl" you need set out support. for other, no need.

hope you like it!

Parametric Scroll Saw Table Insert

Two versions can be printed, one for little clearance around the blade and one for a full 45 degree tilt (make sure to adjust back 45 degrees in your printing software to print this flat). You may enter the thickness and width of your blade to accommodate different style and size blades.

Check comments in the OpenSCAD file for more information on editing the original.

This is my personal collection of 3D printed parts I have modeled around the SL4r frame created by Catalyst Machineworks. Their parts work alright, but I felt the tolerances were a bit too tight, as well as not offering exactly what I was looking for; so I modeled my own.

  • The Camera mount will allow the Runcam Swift to sit lower than the standard mounts.
  • VTX Antenna standoff will allow you to use the standard pigtail that comes with the Unify VTX.
  • LED bar mounts a Matek 8 LED WS2812 to the rear standoffs.
  • The antenna mounts will work on any frame - they just bolt to any frame screw and allow you to stick an antenna tube into it.

title: Prusa i3 Mk2 LED holder with internal cavity for hiding wires

description.text:
After looking at a few LED panel lights on Thingiverse, I decided to make a version that didn't need screws, would fit a small chip on board LED panel, and had an internal cavity to run the wires.

You may have to scale the size of the light housing to fit snugly, but not too tightly into the ball and socket (on my printer, PLA and PLA for both parts fit perfectly, but using ABS for the light housing required a scale increase of 0.5%).

The LED panels used: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/2PCS-free-shipping-Wholesale-White-COB-Chip-LED-Car-Interior-Light-T10-Festoon-ba9s-Dome-Adapter/2037065208.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.8AcmYT

author: sroho

description.text:
So, I decided to make these as currently i could not find any 15 series American aluminum extrusion 3d printed t nuts.

I made 5mm and 3mm compatable tnuts and they require no support so you can make them easily on any 3d printer. You should not need to post process these if your printer is calibrated. Just put in your 3mm or 5mm nut and insert into your extrusion.

I hope you find this useful and beneficial to your project like it has been for mine! Thank you and have a great day!

This set of objects is part of the components of a frame. These parts were specifically designed for the frame of a 3D printer.

This frame uses 3/4" x 3/4" aluminium extrusions. The thickness of the extrusions is 1/16". 3/4" is about 19.05 mm.

In order to build this frame, you will need:

  • 4 of each of the printed parts
  • 4 pieces of 3/4" x 3/4" x X" of aluminium extrusions
  • 4 pieces of 3/4" x 3/4" x Y" of aluminium extrusions
  • 4 pieces of 3/4" x 3/4" x Z" of aluminium extrusions
  • 24 8-32 x 1 1/2" machine screws with their nuts
  • 8 or 16(*) 8-32 x 1 1/4" machine screws with their nuts

For this specific build, X = 500 mm, Y = 400 mm and Z = 450 mm.

Some tabs with pilot holes are included in order to attach an enclosure. The tabs add 10 mm. The screw tabs are 12 mm in length. So, 17 mm is added to the length of the extrusions, 34 mm for both sides. 54 mm if the enclosure attachment tabs are added.

These parts are very easy to print. No support material is needed.

Some add-ons will be published soon under separate things. The end result will be a 3D printer with a build plate of 200 mm (W) x 300 mm (D) x 300 mm (H).

(*) If used with the "Corner Bracket Ortogonal Part V2" instead of the original ones "Corner Bracket Ortogonal Part". The new design gives a little bit more stability.

You can add to the frame some adjustable foot available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2250225

Ivan Miranda (http://ivanmiranda.com/) inspired this design.

description.text: The headset cable on my Oculus rift was starting to kink at the point it leaves the clip on the Rift headset. This strain relief is designed to be placed on the cable and held in place by the clip on the headset, providing additional support and the ability to flex before kinking the Rift headset cable.

Printer:

Davinci XYZ 1.0a

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Printed with Ninjaflex Semi-flex, with cooling, no supports.

After printing, I sliced the flat side all the way down the back with an exacto knife.

Unclip the headset cable from the Rift. Then place the strain relief on the Rift cable.

Test fit the strain relief and clip. Make sure the relief is in an appropriate position.

Then use a flexible cement (such as the E6000 flexible cement I used) to glue the split in the strain relief back together. After that has solidified, I used more cement to build up a few more layers for strength.

After it has fully cured, clip everything back together.

title: Floating LED Light for Prusa i3

description.text:
This a holder for an LED light. You see it on my Original Prusa i3 MK2 in the photos. I believe it'll fit other similar printers that use a 30mm cooling fan.

It swivels to aim the light where you want it. The Floating LED Light has two hinges for adjusting the position of the LED. These hinges allow you to aim the light and swing it in or out.

More info and videos on my web site at Maximpulse.com.

Easy to install. Remove two screws from the 30mm fan and replace them with new screws 7mm longer. Clips to help hold the USB cable as it snakes through the tight spaces on the Prusa.

All the parts are here to print out and make your own.
I also have sets of parts for sale on my Etsy store
You can either order

  1. the complete set of printed parts, USB cable, clips, LED, screws & nuts and zip-tie (17 pieces) or
  2. just the LED, screws & nuts and zip-tie (8 pieces). You print the plastic parts and supply your own USB cable.

I have printed the Floating LED Light in PLA, but pretty much any kind of filament would probably work.

Swiveling: https://youtu.be/K0zUqF4ar5s

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I've been printing these in PLA. ABS should work, too.
I print these at .3 mm layers, but obviously smaller layers would work, too.

Drill out the holes, if necessary

Sometimes the holes for the 3mm screws come out a bit squashed.
That is remedied by drilling out a 3mm or 1/8" hole.
Or a little filing with a small round file does the trick, too.

The screws required are two 3mm x 25mm, two 3mm x 30mm and two 3mm nuts.
I purposefully made the recesses for the nuts a tight fit. The nuts will snap in, but they may require a tap to seat them.

I have how-to videos on my website at Maximpulse.com
You might want to watch them for assembly instructions and to see how to snake the USB cable.
Click here for a how-to-assemble the printed parts video.

How this improvement came about

I love my Prusa i3 MK2 printer. It has made wonderful things possible for me.
But there is always a shadow under the extruder which means it's hard to see what's printing.
So I came up with an LED light that floats along with the extruder, illuminating the area under the nozzle.
These improvements were a bit tricky as Josef Prusa didn't leave much room to fit anything additional on his marvelous printer.

description.text:
This is a bracket that can be used to hang an RC Wing or Plane on the wall. It was designed to print efficiently with no support material.

The bracket fixes to the wall with a single no. 8 screw that allows it to rotate so that it meets the wing profile of whatever you hold with it.

The geometry has just been eyeballed, there's nothing special about it but after testing a number of different models it seems to work well both for wings that lay flat and also that have a fuselage that protrudes beneath the wing.

title: Real basic led-lamp V1.0
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to challenge my self with making a simple LED lamp. So I started designing a little lamp in SketchUp, and this was the result. Learned a lot of new things and my soldering skill have been challenged.

The lamp is designed to be easy printable, but it will take a lot of time to print some parts. Non of the parts do really need some support, but I did add a little to the lampshade just to be sure.

Printer:

CraftBot 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Total printing time is around : 15 hours
Unfortunately I used SketchUp to draw the lamp. One of the limitations in SketchUp is that you can not make true round object. You are limited the to number of segments for a curve. So when printing I saw that the curves were not round but squared off a little. Despite this issue I like the look of the lamp. Maybe I will remake the lamp in a different program for some better curves.
This is the completed lamp, how I wanted it to look like All the part separated, and some combined so I could check if it would fit together

What I used:

  • 5x 5 mm White LED 10000mcd 20° 20 mA 3.2 V
  • 1x resistor 220 Ohm
  • Switch
  • Some cable
  • Universal power supply 3-24V set to 18V
This is the schematic I used

Instead of stacking coins, paper or small wood chips, why not make something that is suited for the purpose. The STLs herein are just examples. description.text:
I finally learned how to make proper knurling.
I plan to make multiple sizes just because I enjoy making them.

This actually make great and silent fidgets. :)

  • After a test print, I decided to take the knurling all the way to a point.
  • Version 2 has a larger chamfer and coarser knurling.
  • Version 3 has the proper size hex socket... it should NOT match the shaft size :)
  • Version 4 has better fit on the hex socket (slight taper)
  • Added washer
  • Added sets
  • Clearer file names

Feel free to send me a message if you have any special requests.

Printer:

Micromake D1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

10 to 100 Percent

Notes:
  • I recommend at least 3 shells/outlines
  • Nuts are pretty strong at 10%
  • Botls, especially longs ones need higher infill
  • Having a cheap tap and die set can help you make these work better.

This spinner uses (6) 12mm ball bearings and one 608 bearing.
and some lovely feeling :))

A simple filament guide for IKEA Stuva based cabinets. Inner hole diameter 4 mm, outer hole 6mm.

TLDR:

  1. Print out TWO parts.
  2. Drill a single 6mm hole in the middle of the IKEA Stuva cabinet ceiling. (Maybe a tiny bit forward, rather than center - at least for Duplicator i3 the filament tends to grind on the frame if it comes directly from above.
  3. Place the two parts from the opposing sides to the hole. Make them hold using superglue.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
I recently upgraded my Wanhao Di3 to a RAMPS v1.4 running Repetier v0.92.9, partly as I wanted some extra functionality with the latest release and more control and also because I have had 2 Melzi boards fail on me now within 18 months!

The upgrade wasn't too hard but takes a bit of time getting everything calibrated and functioning correctly, one of the issues I found was tuning the steps per mm for the X, Y and Z axis (to a decent tolerance).

https://youtu.be/sEtmlaI2Q9c

This is where the Axis Caliper Alignment Jig came about, the video should explain everything and this should work on most metal framed Prusa variants, but I am sure this is easily remixed to accommodate most printer setups.

All parts are designed to be printed without support, see the orientation image for the main caliper block, the angled edges are all above 45 degs.

Couple of further notes:

1) I only show Repetier software here, it is also possible to enter Gcode directly to produce the same result.

2) The caliper used is just a cheap one from Aliexpress and is probably the most common form factor, so the jig should be widely useable. If it doesn't quite fit, my excuse is I didn't have a caliper to measure the caliper, but should be ok as I made 2 prior prototypes to tune it to a satisfactory level.
